doc.title: 2Q Wrap - Solid Growth, Nigeria Accelerates
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Barclays/African Telcos 2Q Wrap - Solid Growth Nigeria AcceleratesAfrican Telcos 2Q Wrap - Solid Growth Nigeria Accelerates_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Barclays
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Barclays

passages.text: African telecom operators continue to benefit from strong data demand and smartphone adoption, with Nigeria leading the charge thanks to well- received price hikes. In contrast, South Africa faces muted momentum amid fierce prepaid competition. We retain our preference for AAF and Safaricom.

Service revenue growth intact: We believe the African Telcos are benefiting from solid growth levers in most markets - with South Africa the only real exception. Data usage continues to grow across the markets, and with growing smartphone penetration we see stronger demand in coming years. In 1H25, MTN reported \(+22.4\%\) yoy service revenue growth (organic, constant FX) (1H24: \(+12.1\%\) ), while Airtel Africa revenue grew \(+24.9\%\) yoy in 1Q26 (4Q25: \(23.2\%\) ). Vodacom posted \(+13.8\%\) in 1Q26 (4Q25: \(+13.5\%\) ). South Africa's competitive landscape is challenging and we expect service revenue growth to remain modest for the remainder of the year. In contrast, Nigeria's recent price increases have been well received, and we expect this to support stronger revenue growth in the second half. Mobile money continues to be a key growth engine for both MTN and Airtel Africa. Despite some delays in monetization, the segment is showing healthy expansion, partly driven by rising smartphone adoption. With ongoing investments in distribution and fintech use cases, we are positive on the outlook for mobile money through the rest of the year.

Nigeria accelerates, South Africa muted: Nigeria's telecom sector continues to outperform, with price hikes driving strong revenue and EBITDA growth for both Airtel Africa and MTN in 2Q25. The adjustments were well absorbed, with minimal impact on voice usage and sustained momentum in data demand. MTN upgraded its guidance post- results, citing pricing traction. In contrast, we see muted outlook for South Africa for FY26 amid fierce prepaid competition. Telkom (not covered) and Vodacom are leaning on regional strategies and localized offers, while MTN has revised its growth outlook to a broader low- to- mid single- digit range. With all players focused on prepaid competitive intensity is set to keep growth subdued.

Valuation: We consider Safaricom to be the most undervalued African Telco. Safaricom has historically traded at a premium valuation to CEEMEA peers, but has de- rated materially over the past couple of years, mostly on Ethiopia and macro concerns, with the stock now trading on \(5x^{1}26\) EV/EBITDA and \(7.4x\) OpFCF. Our price target remains unchanged at KES31. We are OW AAF where growth remains strong, aided by Nigeria pricing tailwind and recovery in Ffranchophone African region growth. We estimate AAF trades on just \(5.6x\) FY26e EV/EBITDA, \(8.1x\)
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 24. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 18:33 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 03:00 GMT Restricted - External
Emerging Markets Telecoms NEUTRAL Unchanged
Emerging Markets Telecoms

EV/OpFCF and a \(\sim 7\%\) unlevered FCF yield. Post result update, our price target increases to £2.40 vs £2.10 prior. We maintain an Equal Weight rating on Vodacom. While its Egypt and international operations continue to deliver robust growth, performance in the domestic South African market remains subdued. We increase our price target to ZAR125 vs ZAR115 prior. We remain Underweight on MTN, which trades at 5.8x 2025e EV/EBITDA and 9.4x EV/OpFCF. For MTN we continue to see domestic market challenged with increased competition. Post result update, our DCF- based target is at ZAR135 vs ZAR130 prior.
Summary of our Ratings, Price Targets and Earnings Changes in this Report (all changes are shown in bold)

Source: Barclays Research. Share prices and target prices are shown in the primary listing currency and EPS estimates are shown in the reporting currency. FY1(E): Current fiscal year estimates by Barclays Research. FY2(E): Next fiscal year estimates by Barclays Research. Stock Rating: OW: Overweight; EW: Equal Weight; UW: Underweight; RS: Rating Suspended Industry View: Pos: Positive; Neu: Neutral; Neg: Negative.

The following company is not under coverage by Barclays Research: Telkom (TKG.J). Information about this company is being provided for information purposes only and is not an investment recommendation by Barclays Research.

As South Africa's mobile market intensifies, MTN, Vodacom, and Telkom are recalibrating their strategies to defend and grow revenue. MTN revised its service revenue and margin guidance downward, acknowledging fierce prepaid competition, but remains focused on tactical investments to regain momentum. Vodacom is leveraging contract growth and loyalty- driven tools like Vodapay to offset prepaid softness, maintaining its growth targets. Telkom, meanwhile, is expanding in underserved regions with a data- led approach, actively managing its base and selectively applying price increases to sustain momentum. We expect tepid growth to continue in South African market in 2H.

- MTN South Africa: Revenue Realism, Margin Reset: MTN revised its South Africa service revenue guidance from "mid-single digits" (previously interpreted as 4-6%) to a broader range of low to mid-single digits, acknowledging intensified competition in the prepaid segment, with rivals Vodacom and Telkom aggressively pursuing market share. Despite reporting 2.3% year-over-year growth in service revenue for H1, management emphasized that the top end of the range remains achievable, and the adjustment reflects current market realities—not a shift in ambition. To regain momentum, MTN is investing in distribution and device strategies, including commission optimization and regionalized offers, while maintaining strong network quality. Concurrently, MTN revised its EBITDA margin guidance down to 35-37% (from 37-39%), citing tactical investments in prepaid. However, the company remains committed to medium-term margin recovery, supported by structural efficiencies and disciplined capital allocation.

- Vodacom South Africa: Contract Strength Cushions Prepaid Strain: Vodacom expects South Africa to grow at or slightly above inflation in FY2026. Management is doubling down on prepaid recovery through targeted regional offers, loyalty-linked incentives via Vodapay, and smartphone upgrades. Despite prepaid pressure, Vodacom maintained its \(\sim 4\%\) EBITDA growth ambition, citing strong cost discipline and stable competition among major players, though MVNOs are adding pricing noise.

- Telkom South Africa: Data-Led Growth Amid Competitive Shifts: Telkom management reported a solid start to FY2026, with mobile service revenue \(+7.8\%\) in 1QFY26. While prepaid ARPU declined due to expansion in lower-income non-metro regions, Telkom emphasized that this was a strategic move to capture underserved markets, with regional activations improving acquisition share. The company stated that price increases, including on social bundles, were selectively applied and have been well received, with no major churn impact. Management remains confident in sustaining mid-single-digit growth, supported by targeted regional strategies, active base management, and continued investment in network capacity.
Prepaid subscriber growth remains muted while Postpaid continues to grow

All three major operators reported muted growth in their prepaid subscriber bases. Vodacom maintained a stable prepaid base after churning inactive users last quarter. MTN added 480k prepaid subscribers, driven by refreshed regional and location- centric propositions. Telkom led the prepaid charge with 603k net additions, supported by a \(5.4\%\) increase in acquisition share across underserved regions, thanks to targeted regional activations and its Customer Value Management initiative. On the postpaid front, MTN topped the segment with 86k net adds, followed by Telkom with a 40k increase, while Vodacom remained steady.
FIGURE 1. South Africa: Prepaid mobile subscriber additions (000)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 2. South Africa: Postpaid mobile subscriber additions (000)
Source: Company reports

During 2Q25, prepaid ARPU trends varied sharply across operators. Vodacom posted a robust \(+16\%\) year- over- year increase to ZAR58, largely due to a low prior- year base impacted by inactive customer churn. Adjusting for that, underlying ARPU growth was a more modest \(+3.6\%\) . MTN faced pressure with a \(- 5\%\) decline, while Telkom saw a \(- 5.7\%\) drop, attributed to expansion in lower- ARPU, high- volume non- metro regions. Despite weaker subscriber additions, Vodacom's strong ARPU growth helped maintain broadly stable prepaid service revenue \((- 0.4\%)\) . MTN's prepaid service revenue fell \((- 2.1\%)\) , driven by declining voice usage, though prepaid data revenue offered slight relief. In contrast, Telkom achieved an \(+8.2\%\) increase in prepaid service revenue, powered by mobile data growth.
FIGURE 3. South Africa - Prepaid ARPU growth (\%)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 4. South Africa - Prepaid service revenue growth (\%)
Source: Company reports

Postpaid performance remained strong across all three major operators, with Vodacom leading in ARPU growth, \(+3.6\%\) year- over- year, supported by a March 2025 price increase. This helped boost mobile contract customer revenue by \(+5.3\%\) , driven by its "more- for- more" pricing strategy. MTN saw the highest postpaid service revenue growth at \(+8.3\%\) , fueled by continued subscriber additions and a February price hike, despite stable ARPU \((- 0.4\%)\) . Telkom also posted solid gains, with postpaid service revenue \(+3.7\%\) and ARPU improving \(+2.2\%\) year- over- year, reflecting its steady expansion in the segment.
FIGURE 5. South Africa - Postpaid ARPU growth (%)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 6. South Africa - Postpaid service revenue growth (%)
Source: Company reports

Mobile data remains the cornerstone of revenue growth for telecom operators, now contributing over half of total mobile revenue. In Q2 2025, Telkom stood out with a sharp rise in data subscribers, who now represent the majority of its mobile base. While peers like Vodacom and MTN saw more subdued data subscriber growth, Telkom's focused strategy—targeting underserved regions and actively managing new subscriber engagement—continues to drive momentum. The company aims to sustain high data revenue share by maximizing usage among new users and maintaining strong conversion from traffic to revenue.
FIGURE 7. South Africa - Mobile data subscriber additions (000)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 8. South Africa - Data usage per subscriber per month (GB)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 9. South Africa - Teleco revenue breakup
Source: Company reports, ICASA
FIGURE 10. South Africa - Mobile revenue breakup
Source: Company reports, ICASA
FIGURE 11. South Africa - Mobile subscriber breakup
FIGURE 12. South Africa - Prepaid mobile subscriber market share
Source: Company reports, ICASA
Source: Company reports, ICASA
FIGURE 13. South Africa - Postpaid mobile subscriber market share
FIGURE 14. South Africa - Smartphone penetration
Source: Company reports, ICASA
Source: Company reports, ICASA

Nigeria - Pricing supports the recoveryPrice hikes have clearly fueled revenue and EBITDA growth for both Airtel Africa and MTN in the quarter ending June 2025. The adjustment landed smoothly, with only a minor dip in voice usage, while data demand remains strong and continues to expand. Following the 2Q25 results, MTN has upgraded its service revenue and EBITDA guidance, citing solid support from the pricing strategy. We expect Nigeria's performance for both operators to stay robust through 2025.

Macroeconomic conditions in Nigeria were stable through 2Q25. Following last year's devaluation, the Naira vs USD held broadly steady during the quarter, while inflation showed signs of moderation—a positive trend for the operating environment. However, persistently high diesel prices continue to pose a challenge, as energy remains a significant cost driver for telecom operators.
FIGURE 15. Nigeria inflation rate (y/y %)
Source: Nigeria Data Portal
FIGURE 16. Nigeria diesel prices (NGN/ltr)
Source: Nigeria Data Portal

Voice and data subscriber addition slowed during the quarter for both Airtel Africa and MTN. The additions were partly impacted by regulatory change restricting SIM registration by third- party agents and dealers to one SIM card per customer and technical challenges with the National Identity Management Commission's NIN verification platform.
FIGURE 17. Nigeria - Voice subscriber net adds (000)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 18. Nigeria - Data subscriber net adds (000)
Source: Company reports

Voice and Data ARPU for both Airtel Africa and MTN improved during the quarter driven by price adjustments. Airtel Africa Voice/data ARPU improved \(+29.3\% / + 46.8\%\) , while for MTN it improved \(+42.5\% / + 65\%\) respectively.
FIGURE 19. Nigeria - Voice ARPU (NGN)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 20. Nigeria - Data ARPU (NGN)
Source: Company reports

While minutes of use per subscriber declined slightly due to price elasticity and a shift to OTT platforms like WhatsApp, both MTN Nigeria and Airtel Africa management affirmed that overall volume growth per subscriber remains stable. Airtel Africa experienced a slowdown in voice consumption during the quarter, but data usage stayed strong. MTN Nigeria, in particular, saw average data usage per subscriber rise by \(21.1\%\) in Q2 to 13.5GB, driving a \(36.4\%\) increase in total traffic. MTN management highlighted this as evidence of sustained structural demand for data, noting that Nigeria's per-subscriber data consumption ranks among the highest in Africa, supported by low pricing and limited access to free Wi- Fi.
FIGURE 21. AAF Nigeria - MOU/Sub
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 22. AAF Nigeria - Data usage per active subscriber (GB/month)
Source: Company reports

Revenue and EBITDA growth for both Airtel Africa and MTN accelerated during the quarter driven by price hike adjustments. MTN Nigeria upgraded full- year guidance, targeting service revenue growth and EBITDA margins in the low- \(50\%\) range, and expressed confidence in sustaining growth through its Ambition 2025 strategy focused on digital transformation and cost discipline.
FIGURE 23. Nigeria - Revenue growth (\%)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 24. Nigeria - EBITDA growth (\%)
Source: Company reports

Mobile money revenue grew by \(30.3\%\) in constant currency driven by revenue growth in both East Africa and Francophone Africa of \(29.6\%\) and \(30.7\%\) , respectively. Revenue growth was driven by both customer base growth and ARPU improvement. Mobile money revenue now contributes \(27\%\) of Airtel Africa total group revenue (excluding Nigeria) - still well below Safaricom at \(40\%\) .
FIGURE 25. AAF - Mobile money revenue (\$m) and growth (\%)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 26. AAF - Mobile money EBITDA (\$m) and margin (\%)
Source: Company reports

While mobile money EBITDA growth slowed during the quarter, it was still close to \(+30\%\) . Mobile money EBITDA improved \(+28.2\%\) y/y, with margin slightly soft with - 90bps to \(52.7\%\) on account of higher sales and marketing spend.
FIGURE 27. AAF - Mobile money EBITDA growth (\%)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 28. AAF - Mobile money ARPU (\$) and constant currency ARPU growth (\%)
Source: Company reports

ARPU growth was supported by the increased range of services on offer, resulting in transaction value growth of \(14.9\%\) (cc) to \$298 per customer per month. Annualised transaction value amounted to \$162bn in reported currency. With over \(90\%\) of transactions in cash and \(65\%\) to \(70\%\) of adults unbanked, AAF has potential opportunity for further customer base growth.
FIGURE 29. AAF - Mobile money customer base (m)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 30. AAF - Mobile money transaction value (\$bn)
Source: Company reports

The volume of fintech transactions volume was \(+14.5\%\) to 5.6bn during 2Q25 for MTN, and the transaction value was \(+45.4\%\) to \$116.9bn. The number of active merchants accepting MoMo payments increased to 2m vs. 1.9m in 1Q25. Ghana, Uganda, and Rwanda were key drivers of MoMo revenue growth, which rose by \(25.6\%\) . This was largely fueled by a \(42.0\%\) surge in advanced services revenue. Basic services revenue also saw an increase of \(18.8\%\) . As a result, the share of advanced services in total MoMo revenue (excluding airtime advance) climbed to \(33.4\%\) in H1, marking a year- on- year rise of 3.8 percentage points.
FIGURE 31. MTN - Mobile money transaction volume (bn)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 32. MTN - Mobile money transaction value (\$bn)
Source: Company reports
After declining 1m in 1Q25, active MoMo users additions rebounded and improved +1m during 2Q.
FIGURE 33. MTN - Active MoMo users (m)
Source: Company reports
FIGURE 34. MTN - active mobile money subscribers additions (000)
Source: Company reports

Airtel Africa (OW, PT £2.40 vs £2.10 previously): We maintain our Overweight rating on Airtel Africa, supported by: a) Nigeria momentum: Following a successful price increase, we anticipate a rebound in both revenue and EBITDA growth in FY26E. b) Francophone Africa recovery: After being a drag on group performance last year, EBITDA growth in the Francophone segment picked up since 4Q25. Management remains optimistic, citing opportunities from increased penetration and the ongoing transition from 2G to 4G handsets in the region. c) Resilient mobile money growth: The mobile money segment continues to grow at a robust pace of around \(+30\%\) and we do not expect any major headwinds near term. We have revised our DCF and SOTP- based target price upward to £2.40 per share (from £2.10) post 1Q26 result update.

Safaricom (OW, PT KES31): We maintain our Overweight rating on Safaricom: a) We anticipate the Ethiopia operation to achieve EBITDA breakeven by FY27E, in line with the company's guidance. b) We expect robust growth of Kenya's M- Pesa to continue. c) Although Safaricom has historically traded at a premium valuation compared to CEEMEA peers, it experienced a significant de- rating last year, primarily due to concerns about Ethiopia and macroeconomic factors. Currently, the stock is trading at 5x '26e EV/EBITDA and 7.4x OpFCF.

Vodacom (EW, ZAR125 vs ZAR115 prior): We remain Equal Weight on Vodacom. We see Egypt remaining the major revenue and EBITDA growth driver for the group and see International rebounding in FY26E with growth across the segment and recovery in Mozambique. We expect tepid growth in South Africa in FY26E with increased competition from Telkom in prepaid segment. On a proportionate basis, we see the stock trading on 6.9x '26e EV/EBITDA and 10.7x EV/OpFCF.

MTN (UW, ZAR135 vs ZAR130 prior): We remain Underweight on MTN. We expect performance in Nigeria and Ghana to remain robust in- line with the upgraded outlook. However, in South Africa, we have revised down our service revenue and EBITDA estimates broadly in- line with company guidance. We also note the group is being investigated by the US Department of Justice through a grand jury inquiry related to its subsidiary in Afghanistan and Iran, which remains a stock overhang. Post result and forex update, our price target has increased to ZAR135 vs ZAR130 prior. On our estimates MTN trades at 5.8x FY25E and 9.4x EV/OpFCF.

Changes to estimatesPost 1Q26 results, we refresh our Airtel Africa estimates. Our revenue and EBITDA estimates increase by \(+2.1\% / + 2.9\%\) in 2026E and \(+3.2\% / + 4.1\%\) in 2027E, respectively mainly driven by strong results in Nigeria and Franchophone region. Post result update, with higher EBITDA estimates, our DCF based price target increases to £2.40 vs £2.10 prior. We previously used group DCF with \(17\%\) WACC and \(7\%\) terminal growth, but now model mobile services and mobile money separately using WACC / terminal growth of \(20\% / 4\%\) and \(12\% / 5\%\) respectively for the two segments.
FIGURE 35. Airtel Africa - Changes to estimates (\$m)
Source: Barclays Research estimates

We update our Vodacom estimates for latest forex movements. Our model now also includes the Maziv deal (Vodacom buying \(30\%\) interest, likely to be completed in 2H26), which leads to ZAR7.9bn increase in net debt and corresponding increase in finance costs. We assume JV dividend payment to accrue from 2028E. Our new DCF- based PT of ZAR 125 (ZAR 115 prior) is based on \(14\%\) WACC and terminal growth of \(3\%\) in South Africa (previously \(16\%\) WACC and \(4\%\) growth).
FIGURE 36. Vodacom - Changes to estimates (ZARm)
Source: Barclays Research estimates
Barclays | African Telcos

We refresh our MTN estimates for 2Q25 results. Post results update, our DCF based price target slightly increased to ZAR135 vs ZAR130 prior (unchanged WACC and terminal growth for South Africa and Nigeria segment).
FIGURE 37. MTN - Changes to estimates (ZARm)
Source: Barclays Research estimates

Price (27-Aug-2025) GBP 2.23
Price Target GBP 2.40

Airtel Africa is a leading operator or challenger in Nigeria and other African countries, consistently delivering solid organic constant FX revenue/EBITDA growth. We see strong continued growth in service revenues and FCF, mostly driven by mobile money which is becoming an increasingly important part of the business.
**Upside case** GBP 2.75 Our upside case is based on realization of higher multiple in mobile money business than our estimate.

**Downside case** GBP 1.00 Cash repatriation has been a key challenge as AAF operates in difficult markets where there is always regulatory/competition uncertainty. Airtel Africa could derate due to increasing competition in its markets, USD appreciation & EM stocks could fall out of favour.

Valuation Methodology: We value Airtel Africa using a DCF and SOTP methodology, based on WACC / terminal growth of \(20\% /4\%\) for mobile services and \(12\% /5\%\) for mobile money segments.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The main risk is delivery of FCF (EBITDA, capex and other factors such as leases, working capital, interest and tax) given the uncertain macro and competitive backdrop, and issues with repatriating FCF from the OpCos.

Valuation Methodology: We value MTN using DCF methodology. In South Africa we use WACC of \(14\%\) and assume terminal growth rate of \(3\%\) , while in Nigeria our WACC and terminal growth rate at \(20\% /4\%\) respectively.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: We see two main risks to our UW rating. Firstly, the company executes on its ZAR25bn ARP plan (disposal of non- core assets) for valuations ahead of our forecasts. Secondly, the company successfully repatriates FCF from Nigeria/Other geographies that boosts the dividend.

Valuation Methodology: We value Safaricom using DCF methodology. We use a \(17\%\) WACC and \(7\%\) terminal growth. We include a lease adjustment in the model. Safaricom started its commercial operation in Ethiopia, which is a high inflationary economy and as such it can pose significant risk to investment case.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Key downside risk is regulatory consultation on interoperability of M- Pesa agents poses a potential threat to Safaricom's dominance. Deterioration in Ethiopian economy more than our estimate also pose downside risk to the stock.
Valuation Methodology: Our price target is based on a discounted cash flow model, using a WACC of \(13\%\) . We discount group FCF in Brazilian Real. We assume a terminal growth rate of \(3.5\%\) .

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Upside risks include further improvement of the macro and competitive environment. Downside risks include deterioration of the macro economic environment and a breakdown of pricing discipline.

Valuation Methodology: Our price target is based on our sum- of- the- parts calculation in which we use our discounted cash flow analysis to value certain parts, assuming a WACC of \(13\%\) and perpetual growth rate of \(3.5\%\) .

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The main downside risks that we see are 1) No improvement in the macro environment or 2) Renewed competition in mobile. The main upside risks are 1) Market consolidation and 2) better macro.

Valuation Methodology: We value Vodacom using DCF methodology. We use a WACC of \(14\%\) , and terminal growth of \(3\%\) in South Africa. We include an IFRS16 lease adjustment and spectrum adjustment.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The key downside risk is slower growth in South Africa. We believe tougher macro conditions can hurt service revenue growth for the company. A key upside risk could include more- than- expected growth of mobile money operation in South Africa.
Source: Barclays Research

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
